------=_NextPart_000_059C_01CA7246.BD4C4590
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

@Colin,
 
I can assure you that neuroevolution and NEAT / HyperNEAT derivatives are
very much in the scientific research domain. 
 
I think the lack of generally published work is due to the Nicolas Bourbaki
syndrome - some of the outcomes of this work are so disruptive, publishing
can be dangerous to one's career. It's not just for Checkers and evolving
pictures, you know?
 
 
@Ken Stanley
 
Thanks for the reference to quark paper.  Generalized, this serves as a
paradigm for studying many important phenomena
 
Ken Lloyd


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Colin
Green
Sent: Monday, November 30, 2009 3:40 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Practical Applications


  

2009/11/29 Ken <kstanley@cs. <mailto:kstanley%40cs.utexas.edu> utexas.edu>
>
>
> One recent interesting real-world success is the most accurate measurement
yet of the top quark mass at the Fermilab accelerator:
>

Ken, that was very modestly put :) Seems to me that this is a very
prominent piece of research that could be a real boon to NEAT in terms
of exposure in the wider research community. I wonder what the back
story is there - perhaps Aaltonen or one of the other authors arived
at the conclusion that they needed something akin to neuro evolution
and discovered NEAT via a search. Or perhaps there was some connection
at a cross discipline conference?

Anyway, I feel like congratulations are in order.

Colin.
